16. His playing was perceived as far sweeter
at another time, when he sang
of young maidens who come to grief,
driven by foolish love.
Notice how we have leapt into this tale,
to show that one is sometimes forced
to make such changes, according to
the style and action of our subject.

17. Similarly, when one makes standing figures
who are wielding stakes or pulling ropes,
the feet and hands must extend on the same side,
as well as the arms and legs that stretch together
in the direction that the action demands.
But one must especially avoid covering
the naked Body with the arms, so that
if possible it is unencumbered by all limbs.
right-middleOn depicting figures in action, positioning the limbs according to their activity.
right-middleOn not hiding the beauty of the body, and never obstructing its contours.

18. Thus we must further (according to our knowledge)
consider an improperly done figure,
as when a figure is sitting
with the feet turned out sideways
and the knees bent inward towards one another.
This would not be praised; rather, it would be much better
to let the knees bend outward
and the heels inward, to enjoy a proper appearance.
right-middle How the knees of a seated figure should and should not bend.

19. Indeed, making the feet of a woman
too far apart when lying or standing,
especially when standing, is to be untrue
to the correct manner, which demands that
the feet be close together, for the sake of decorum.
Then at times, one must also avoid inappropriate
foreshortening of faces and so forth,
since too much of this would lack grace.
right-middleHow the legs and feet of a female figure should be placed.
right-middleToo much foreshortening is not praiseworthy.

20. Furthermore, many renowned painters (like the lame)
wander on a curious wrong path,
that is: (if they will not blame me, but thank me)
they lift and raise the shoulder highest
over the hip which they allow to swing out,
while it should always drop lower over the hip which swings out.
For this is the essence of art,
whether the figure is sitting, lying or standing.
right-middle How a figure should move.

21. Further, there is another mark of folly,
when one allows the arm of the lower shoulder,
where the body swings out, to reach upward.
